title: Friday, 30th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

Spent all morning looking for this market rout

PM11:01am

Without luck

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Mixed back of stuff this morning

PM11:01am

There's not much formal corporate news

PM11:01am

But there's other stuff

11:01 am
PM11:02am

And some float stuff to discuss

PM11:02am

But first you need a pic

PM11:02am

Well, you are getting a pick

11:02 am
PM11:02am

https://twitter.com/brianstelter/status/880440204204666881

PM11:02am

Just a quick reminder that he's still in the White House -- having a Mika Meltdown

undefined
11:02 am
PM11:03am

Anyway,

PM11:03am

Bryce, what do we discuss first?

PM11:03am

I could share some more of that Michael Hartnett stuff I put up earlier

11:03 am
PM11:03am

https://ftalphavil...to-kill-than-fear/

BE11:04am

Go ahead.

PM11:04am

Talking Points
Today marks 10 year anniversary of first generation iPhone (6/29/2007): tech Disruption + excess Debt + aging Demographics = Deflationary macro past decade and reason for central bank War on Deflation (zero rates, liquidity supernova) past decade.

Massive outperformance of deflation assets versus inflation assets (Chart 1) shows central bank failure in War on Deflation...they have failed to boost wage expectations, inflation expectation, "animal spirits" on Main St.

Put another way, central banks have exacerbated inequality via Wall St inflation & Main St deflation (Chart 6); no longer politically acceptable to stoke Wall St bubble; two ways to cure inequality... you can make the poor richer...or you can make the rich poorer...Fed/ECB now tightening to make Wall St poorer.

Tightening by Fed, rhetorical tightening by ECB has succeeded in raising bond yields, volatility, reducing tech stocks (CCMP, QNET, SOX all at 1-month lows); flow data had indicated tech very overbought (Chart 2- flows into tech annualizing 22% AUM YTD), ripe for correction; EM debt & US/EU corporate bonds other crowded areas...look at surge in inflows to EU credit funds (Chart 3).

We don't think this is "big top" in stocks; actually would be surprised if bull market which began with SPX 666 ends before we see 6666 on CCMP.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Note central banks in aggregate still printing: bought $350bn in April, $300bn in May,

63% all-time high; cash levels high; BofAML Bull & Bear index at 7, not yet 8. This week Healthcare funds saw second biggest inflow in two years (Chart 4).

And "greed" takes longer to kill than "fear": Nasdaq corrected

10% on six separate occasions in 12 months leading up to tech bubble peak.

CCMP at 6000, SOX at 1000 likely to attract buyers.

PM11:04am

Sorry for the formatting

PM11:04am

Equity-bond disconnect view a myth, stocks falling now because yields have gone up; get back into tech and equities for another leg higher, but we're more reluctant on EM debt and HY given vulnerability to rising yields.

Asset allocators should nonetheless start buying vol, reducing exposure to credit, prepare for bout of higher yields...summer 2017 = significant inflection point in central bank liquidity trade…will likely lead to "Humpty-Dumpty" big fall in market in autumn, in our view.

Central banks want volatility to return, know financial conditions too easy (Chart 5); yields rise as they carry through on threat (or as ECB shows this week, lose credibility by lame flip-flop on policy intentions as Euro moved toward ECB "pain threshold" - Chart 7); ECB sets interest rate floor and floor now rising.

11:04 am
PM11:05am

But Big Top likely occurs when Peak Liquidity meets Peak Profits. We think that's an autumn not summer story.

US EPS growth forecasts currently at 10.4%, highest in six years. Breakeven inflation rates lead EPS forecasts by roughly six months (Chart 8) and have fallen steadily since March. EPS forecasts will peak in Q3 (PMI's give similar read). Five-year breakeven rates (currently 1.65%) would need to drop below 1% to imply negative profit growth by year-end.

PM11:05am

Summer trade arguably optionality in tech (uber growth), long banks/energy (uber value), lighten up in credit, EM, add to volatility.

Central banks making mistake tightening policy as there is no inflation. Disruption, Demographics (Chart 9), Debt (IIF just announced global debt hit all-time high of $217tn = 327% of global GDP in Q1, up $50tn past decade)...all means normal business upturn cannot create inflation...oil prices poster child for this (we cut oil price forecasts today - link)...all means the big inflation rotation awaits radical fiscal stimulus, trade war, major increase in geopolitical risk, Occupy Silicon Valley policies (tech taxation, living wages...).

Table below shows winners & losers from QE era.

PM11:05am

Oh -- i should get that table for you

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Give me a mo

PM11:06am

PM11:06am

Right click, new tab to read

11:06 am
PM11:07am

Worth studying

undefined
PM11:07am

So the Footsie's up

11:07 am
BE11:07am

A tad.

PM11:08am

Yeah, but completely ignoring Wall St overnight

BE11:08am

Though you'll be searching for a while to find any overarching theme. Feels very slow, almost August-ish.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

FTSE ahead 0.1% at 7360 at pixel.

BE11:08am

Rebounds, rallies and bounces, mostly.

BE11:09am

Such as Burberry, which has been knocked around mostly by sterling all week.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Though also, as a secondary effect, by an analyst tour of its Regent Street shop.

BE11:09am

Where the ........ CFO, I think? .......... said nothing much of consequence.

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,680, up 27 (+1.63%), High: 1,688, Low: 1,645, Volume: 350.86k
11:10 am
PM11:10am

Stock is no2 n the footsie leader board

BE11:11am

As I say, it's come off quite a bit this week. We can blame the store tour, or the pay fight, but probably shouldn't. Instead, here's RBC pre the Q1 numbers coming up shortly.

BE11:11am

Our view: Cost savings and enhanced cash returns to shareholders provide some support for the stock but Burberry has been trailing its strongest luxury peers on retail LFL momentum and is facing significant headwinds in the US department store channel. Further reinvestment may be required to reignite sales growth in a relatively soft apparel category with Mr Marco Gobbetti assuming the CEO role next week.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Sorry. Not CFO. COO.

BE11:12am

We attended an analyst group store tour and meeting with CFO/
COO Julie Brown earlier this week. Despite positive momentum in handbags, greater confidence on the delivery of gross cost-savings targets (given Julie's strong track record and given some granularity on cost initiatives under-way) and enhanced cash returns announced last month (i.e. distributing the proceeds from the Beauty deal with Coty), we retain our Underperform rating on the stock. This is due to uninspiring retail LFL momentum (trailing its strongest luxury peers) and lingering US wholesale weakness. As a result, we see another year of below-sector-average underlying revenue & earnings growth for Burberry (mid-single- digit EBIT growth vs. low-teen sector average growth, on our estimates). We tweaked our model, but our FY17-18E EPS forecasts are unchanged.

BE11:12am

Key messages from store tour: (a) one label strategy and SKU count reduction making customer journey easier; (b) enhancing novelties across the assortment (with runway particularly strong) to address greater appetite for fashion from millennials; (c) no change in ASP and covering all price points as before; (d) tropical gabardine trenchcoat enjoying very positive customer traction, including local UK clientele; and (e) focus on developing key handbag pillars, with DK88 already ranking among the best-selling shapes (along with The Banner & Rucksack); additional colours and sizes should be introduced (with opportunities across all price points).

11:12 am
BE11:12am

"tropical gabardine trenchcoat"?

PM11:13am

So RBC are very cautious

PM11:13am

With good reason, I'd say.

11:13 am
PM11:13am

I popped in to the end of the sales.

PM11:13am

Big big discounts, bin end stuff etc

PM11:14am

Bought two armani white shirts for 10 quid each in selfridges.

11:14 am
PM11:14am

yes, really. £10 each

BE11:14am

We wrote a month or so ago about the amount Burberry relies on the outlet stores in the US to shift stuff.

BE11:14am

Which dilutes the brand.

11:14 am
PM11:15am

Indeed

BE11:15am

Here, by the way, is a tropical gaberdine trench coat.

BE11:15am

11:15 am
BE11:15am

£1,295: https://uk.burberr...5dQCFSyJ7QodWY0Heg

BE11:15am

If you want.

PM11:15am

Quite stylish, tho

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Yeah, I doubt I'd carry it quite as well given don't look like her.

undefined
PM11:16am

Seen this Morgan Stanley stuff on Reckitt?

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Glanced at it.

PM11:17am

Well, there's two portions of it

PM11:17am

A taste...

11:17 am
PM11:17am

This report is “uncommercial”: deliberately dry title, no estimates, no target prices, no recommendations and no ideas. If you follow RB, we think you should read it.

BE11:17am

.......... hm.

PM11:17am

This is Richard Taylor -- lead analyst

11:17 am
PM11:17am

A Guide to RB

PM11:18am

It then goes on for many many pages of history, with pics

BE11:18am

K.

11:18 am
PM11:18am

And then there's the MS "foundation" research

PM11:18am

Had you come across this foundation tag from them previously?

PM11:18am

By 2020, RB should be one of the fastest growing names in Global Staples, with superior returns and cash generation. Near-term concerns present a standout opportunity. We assume coverage with an Overweight Rating and £100 PT.

11:18 am
PM11:19am

Challenges and Unforced Errors… RB’s long-term track record of strong topline growth, cash generation, ROIC and EPS growth puts the company in the top tier of the FMCG peer group. However, the stock's underperformance vs all major indices and peers over the last 12 months puts it in the bottom tier. Why? A topline slowdown over the last 4 quarters, innovation misfire (Scholl), challenges in Korea (Sanitiser), travails in India (demonetisation/sales tax), fines in Australia (Nurofen), ongoing investigations in the US (Indivior), and the biggest acquisition (Mead Johnson) in RB’s history complete with challenges all of its own. Furthermore, Q217 is likely to be another weak quarter: flat topline, flat margins.

BE11:19am

Yeah, as I understand it they're like York Notes for fund managers. Here's the idea to pitch, no thinking required.

PM11:19am

...Lead to Twin Inflections Ahead…We set out why RB looks cheap (rare) despite twin inflection points ahead. At RB we forecast LFL accelerating from 0% 1H17 to 5% 1H18, driven by easy comparables and legacy issues falling away. And at Mead we forecast topline accelerating from -2% 1H17 to +4% 1H18 driven by easy comparables and corrective measures in China. For the combined group we expect ROIC to rise from c.11% in 2017e to 15.6% by 2020, cashflow generation to rise from £2.8bn to £4.1bn, and net debt / EBITDA to fall from 4.1x to 1.7x. We even expect 20% accretion to EPS from the Mead acquisition by 2020. Is this inflection just going to be optical (easy comps) and mechanical (M&A)? Maybe...

11:19 am
PM11:19am

…But the Real Prize is RB 2020... In this report we present our in-depth analysis of what RB could look like in 2020. We step through what we call the Reckitt Power Playbook (culture, incentives, powerbrands/markets and savings projects) specifically looking at the impact that these initiatives could have on the £200mn cost savings target and 3-5% topline growth guidance. We also reveal a potential £250mn working capital benefit at Mead. Our analysis shows that on all previous large deals (Benckiser, BHI, Adams, SSL) management has over delivered on efficiency AND growth. By 2020, we believe that RB will once again set the growth benchmark for FMCG peers. Right now RB trades on 19x 18e P/E (EPS CAGR 11% F18-20e) vs Colgate on 24x (EPS CAGR 7.4% F18-20e).

PM11:19am

…Standout. Of course, the challenges could persist, but we believe that the near-term concerns make RB the standout opportunity in large cap Global Staples. We see 28% upside on our base case over the next 12 months.

Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,742, up 55 (+0.72%), High: 7,876, Low: 7,685, Volume: 499.13k
11:20 am
BE11:20am

................. Fair enough. As a companion piece to that I'd point readers towards the Reckitt note from Redburn a month or so ago, which was absurdly complicated.

BE11:20am

Deep dives into the dynamics of the Chinese baby milk market, if you can imagine such a thing.

PM11:21am

(Pharma@home -- two separate notes)

11:21 am
BE11:21am

They were extremely positive as a result, and it's well outside my intellectual capacity to argue with Redburn. Here's the gist: https://www.ft.com...7b8a20f23?mhq5j=e3

undefined
BE11:22am

Hurricane requested, somewhat inevitably.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

It has a following.

Hurricane Energy PLC (HUR:LSE): Last: 32.58, down 4.42 (-11.96%), High: 34.25, Low: 31.75, Volume: 26.90m
BE11:22am

And, in the old fashioned way, it's using the equity markets to raise money rather than take money out.

11:22 am
PM11:22am

Dropped straight to the placing price

BE11:23am

Yup. This is $300m placing at 32p/sh combined with a $220m convertible bond offering.

BE11:23am

To fund Lancaster hitting the EPS phase.

11:23 am
PM11:24am

Cenkos did the business

PM11:24am

And Stifel

PM11:24am

Oh and Evercore!

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Three on the ticket for a $520m raise. Thin times out there right now.

BE11:25am

Anyway, have BMO. Who weren't on the ticket.

BE11:25am

Gross proceeds of ~$520 million, before expenses will be allocated to Lancaster EPS development capex, decom pre-funding and G&A. The remaining funding requirement excluding spend to date is anticipated to be $469 million, in line with our expectations.
• Opening Up the Portfolio. We had assumed a $200 million raise at 34p/sh (plus a non-dilutive debt instrument) so anticipate a ~15-20% negative impact to our valuation, although this is likely to be somewhat offset by project de-risking now there is line of sight to first oil in 2019.
• View. Very much a defining moment for the company. The size of the ask from equity markets, and consequent expected dilution, has exceeded our expectations although potential funding of the EPS not only de-risks value there but also potentially unlocks the rest of Hurricane's considerable portfolio. Reiterate Outperform Speculative.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

And RBC ...........

BE11:26am

If the funds are raised it will enable the company to maintain control and momentum of the EPS project with project sanction expected late summer 2017 (first oil in H1/19). However, even if the raise is completed, without further funding (through a farm-out, where discussions continue) there is the risk of a hiatus in material (drilling) news flow over the next two years (ahead of first oil). Indeed unless progress is made on a farm out the stock could drift with medium term demand likely satisfied by the planned (larger than expected) equity raise.

BE11:27am

And Canaccord.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

In our recent note on June 13th, we indicated a possible equity
raise of $250-350m at various share prices. At $300m and 35p/share our projected valuation is 73p/share based on a weighted scenario approach to the DCF valuation at $62.5/bbl LT Brent. There is quite little sensitivity to the equity raise pricing. At 32p/share our projected valuation would potentially decline to 70p/sh. Perhaps the biggest surprise is the lack of bank debt financing in the mix – either due to its unavailability or cost, nor is there any indication of service company or offtake support.

undefined
BE11:28am

While on oil, couple of downgrades of the majors to note.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Merrill, firstly.

BE11:29am

Resets forecasts for $50 oil, so BP and Enquest both go down to "underperform".

BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 446.09, down 3.81 (-0.85%), High: 446.40, Low: 440.45, Volume: 8.92m
11:29 am
EnQuest PLC (ENQ:LSE): Last: 31.53, down 0.7224 (-2.24%), High: 32.00, Low: 31.00, Volume: 3.82m
BE11:29am

Soco down to neutral.

SOCO International PLC (SIA:LSE): Last: 116.25, down 1.25 (-1.06%), High: 117.50, Low: 115.50, Volume: 76.18k
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Though I only have the briefest of explanations available ......

BE11:30am

Downgrades based on "an oil price environment rangebound around $50/bbl [...] at least partially offset by corresponding upward revisions to our European refining margin forecasts."

BE11:30am

Rather more interesting is Kepler, which chucks around the word "bloodbath".

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Big sector note, 70 pages of it, talking about shale flooding the market and crashing Brent.

BE11:31am

Because Permian Basin operators have a breakeven substantially below $30 per barrel

BE11:31am

Here's the page one sum .......

11:31 am
BE11:31am

The US rig count has already crossed the red line. We expect US liquids production to grow at a staggering 1.86mb/d in 2017E (exit to exit). The fact that Permian operators will structurally outspend cash flows by 20- 25% in a USD50/bbl+ world has made us revise down our long-term oil prices from USD60/bbl to USD50/bbl (consensus: USD65/bbl). Our short- term assumptions (Brent USD45/bbl) remain skewed to the downside with asymmetrical risks. The whole sector is in for a rude awakening once it realises the full extent of US shale’s disruptive impact, although downstream provides a buffer. Scrip dividends are here to stay, or dividends will have to be cut.We do not have a single Buy anymore among European Big Oils - Total and Shell are our most defensive names.

BE11:31am

And the page 2 bullet points, to fill out that argument a little.

BE11:31am

We already sounded the alarm in our report, “Prevention is better than cure” by stating that oil prices over USD60/bbl in the next 6-12 months would be self-defeating and would likely end in a bloodbath. The conclusions of today’s report are even more bearish.

11:00 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:32am

· The US rig count has already crossed the red line. Despite our lower oil prices assumptions, we expect US liquids production to grow at a staggering 1.86mb/d in 2017E (exit to exit including 0.54mb/d of NGLs) and by another 1.1mboe/d in 2018E (exit to exit) and a whopping 1.5mboe/d in 2018E (average to average).
· Expect record high OECD inventories to be drawn down only modestly by the end of the year.
· Our short-term assumptions (Brent: USD45/bbl) remain skewed to the downside with asymmetrical risks.

PM11:32am

This is all pretty forceful

11:32 am
BE11:32am

It is.

BE11:32am

· The whole sector is in for a rude awakening once it realises the full extent of US shale’s disruptive impact, although downstream provides a buffer.
· Consensus expectations by 2019-20E remain at USD62-65/bbl.
· Scrip dividends are here to stay, or dividends will have to be cut.

BE11:33am

In terms of the sector, don't buy anything.

11:32 am
BE11:33am

We have cut our cash flow and target prices on average by 12%, downgraded five out of seven stocks under our coverage and no longer have a single Buy rating on European Big Oils. We downgrade: Eni, Repsol, Shell and Total by one notch from Buy to Hold; and BP from Hold to Reduce. No change in ratings for Galp (Hold) and OMV (Reduce). Total and Shell are our most defensive names.

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 2,078, down 16.57 (-0.79%), High: 2,085, Low: 2,062, Volume: 2.12m
undefined
11:33 am
PM11:33am

So Rocket and co got this Delivery Hero thing away

PM11:33am

Trading at 26.70 euros

PM11:34am

Quite a result for them

11:34 am
PM11:34am

And this was despite the dud Blue Apron float in the US yesterday

PM11:34am

Stuck at the $10 sale price

PM11:34am

Is this just German tech investors being behind the curve of their US counterparts?

11:34 am
PM11:35am

I suspect so

PM11:35am

I was about to share Campling's preview for Delivery Hero

PM11:35am

But you've heard his views on this

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Ours echo his

PM11:36am

Instead -- here's an interesting list frm CB Insights

PM11:36am

A downround tracker

11:36 am
PM11:36am

https://www.cbinsi...b286a1663-87499037

PM11:36am

I recommend signing up to their daily email -- it's quite lively

PM11:37am

There's a lot of nonsense there -- looking for a public exit or sale at some stage...

11:37 am
undefined
BE11:37am

So, haven't really had the chance to look into this offer for San Leon from China.

BE11:38am

Tried to Google the buyer, China Great United Petroleum, but rapidly became confused about the several companies sharing that name.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

So anyway, CGUP has been in talks since May 16 under the shield of an NDA

BE11:39am

And has proposed 67-76p/shr

BE11:39am

Can't remember a bid ever going live with a range before, though you often hear them rumoured that way.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Anyway, China Great United expects to be in a position to make a formal offer within 45 days.

BE11:41am

And beyond that, I know nothing. As I say, I've no clarity on the the buyer and it looks like the market doesn't either.

PM11:41am

This all sounds a little random

11:41 am
San Leon Energy PLC (SLE:LSE): Last: 32.50, up 3.25 (+11.11%), High: 45.00, Low: 32.50, Volume: 3.54m
PM11:42am

They havent even nailed down an adviser -- the Chinese, that is

PM11:42am

Seem to be signing with GMP Securities -- of canada, but have yet to do so

11:42 am
BE11:43am

You'll also remember Tosca is a majority holder of San Leon, and has been angling for something to happen for a while.

BE11:43am

It also comes very shortly after San Leon issued shares to something called YA II PN Ltd , an investment fund managed by Yorkville Advisors.

BE11:44am

6.3m shares at a strike of 32p.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Which follows any number of rollovers of its debts. It all feels highly odd and without further info -- which I didn't have time to get this morning, sorry -- I'm a bit loathe to speculate.

BE11:45am

Suffice to say, the 100% discount to offer in the San Leon price is difficult to argue with.

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:45am

While in the dregs ..............

Game Digital PLC (GMD:LSE): Last: 23.25, down 9.75 (-29.55%), High: 25.00, Low: 23.00, Volume: 2.57m
BE11:46am

Yet another warning, of course.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Saying the same thing as all the other warnings.

BE11:47am

As in, its market is in structural decline and whenever there is a new console launch it doesn't have the heft to get hold of enough supplies.

BE11:47am

So, the Nintendo Switch hasn't been the boost to sales that was expected (by people who don't remember Game's long history of not delivering expectations).

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Here comes Liberum.

BE11:48am

Core retail categories remain subdued: trading conditions in the UK retail market have continued to be challenging, with a weaker than expected performance in the core console (Xbox and PlayStation) categories over period February to date. In addition, while the new Nintendo Switch console (released in March) is proving very popular with strong consumer demand, supply of product into the UK has been lower than expected. At this stage, we understand North America and Japan have received the more favourable allocations. This was a risk that management highlighted at the interim results back in March. On a more positive note, the group's Spanish operations are performing well with the division set to achieved record sales in the full year.

BE11:48am

More optimistic for FY18E: management sees more encouraging signs heading into the next financial year. In particular, these include the ongoing strong demand for the new Nintendo console, which should be supported by improved supply, and Microsoft's new Xbox One X console coming to market in November, where pre-orders have been encouraging. A stronger schedule of new software releases across all three platforms(Xbox, PlayStation and Nintendo) is also expected to support growth across both the UK and Spain. Further progress with the UK's BELONG (in-store gaming arenas) continues. There are now 12 locations, which have delivered a strong trading performance and management is considering new (debt) financing options to support a possible acceleration of the roll-out across the UK store base.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

....... gonna go out on a limb here and say that 2018 optimism's misplaced. Hope and experience, etc.

BE11:49am

Operational progress: there has been ongoing strategic progress in the UK. The focus remains on improving supplier arrangements, the customer experience and cost saving initiatives. As a reminder, at the interims UK retail costs fell -6.4%, which included (i) a £2.6m reduction in store payroll and other variable costs, (ii) £0.8m savings in property related costs from rent re-negotiations, (iii) £1.9m of savings from combined distribution efficiencies, marketing savings and procurement benefits. Over the next 12 months, there are more than 200 lease events relating to the UK store base of around 300. In H1 (to end of January) management achieved 22 improved lease terms, with a 44% cost reduction across these properties.

BE11:49am

Consensus forecasts expected to fall: within the statement, management notes that it is still expecting to deliver year-on-year gross transaction value growth in H2 of approximately 5-6%, but this is below previously expectations. We expect forecast consensus FY17E EBITDA to fall to around £6-9m. This compares to our current £19.4m, before today's update.

11:49 am
PM11:49am

So Game is now down about 90% from it post-float high...

BE11:49am

Yeah, that sounds about right.

PM11:50am

I'm sure we've shared the tombstone previously -- but shall i do it again?

11:49 am
PM11:50am

It includes Liberum, btw

BE11:51am

Sure, why not. Though the most important firm to identify is OpCapita, of course, which took Game out of administration in 2012, added "Digital" to its name and floated it again in 2014 for £340m.

BE11:51am

Which remains one of the most brass-balled transactions the public market has ever seen.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

What does the tombstone look like then?

PM11:51am

Apologies in advance for the formatting...

PM11:51am

Financial Adviser, Sole Sponsor and Joint Bookrunner

Canaccord Genuity +44 (0) 20 7523 8000

Alexis de Rosnay

Bruce Garrow

Cara Griffiths

Emma Gabriel

Joint Bookrunner

HSBC +44 (0) 20 7991 8888

Stuart Dickson

Andrew Judge

Richard Fagan

Joint Bookrunner

Liberum +44 (0)20 3100 2222

Peter Tracey

James Staveley

Christopher Britton

Media Enquiries

Citigate Dewe Rogerson +44 (0) 20 7638 9571

Tom Baldock +44 (0) 20 7282 2889

Grant Ringshaw +44 (0) 20 7282 2851

Jos Bieneman +44 (0) 20 7282 1053

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Let me see if there's any sellside from anyone not attached to this hospital case.

BE11:53am

.... Nope. Canaccord's mildly positive tho!

BE11:53am

Demand for the Nintendo product remains strong - supply, both of consoles and software is the issue. On Xbox and Playstation, the slippage of the release date for a major title has been a factor. Pre-owned remains difficult.

Meanwhile, the Spanish business continues to trade well and is on track for a record year of sales. Belong (in-store gaming arenas in the UK) is also progressing well (12 locations) and the company is 'exploring new funding arrangements to enable acceleration of the roll-out'.

The GAME management team is positioning the business well strategically, aided by an average lease length of just 1.2 years and the Belong concept. As so often though, the carpet has been pulled from under their feet by market factors out of their control.

The company maintains its view that FY18 should be a stronger year as Nintendo supply improves and the new Xbox comes to market. There is also a stronger pipeline of software. At this stage, it is clearly difficult to plot the trajectory of any recovery.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

BE12:03pm

Historically, the group has sought to focus on top line growth to drive margin and EBITDA growth – the rationale was certainly compelling with significant leverage possible on the equity.

■ While growth ambitions have not been abandoned (though there are no longer any external targets) the group has now tweaked the tiller to a more balanced approach giving equal standing to cash generation, cost savings and growth – a wholly understandable and sensible strategy, in our view.

BE11:32am

Key findings of the report
· US E&Ps are massively outspending (c. 25%) their cash flows in the Permian (likely a structural feature at USD50/bbl+).
· Our Permian model yields the same supply-growth trajectory using either USD60/bbl and a one-to-one spending rule or USD50/bbl with a 1.2x spending rule.
· We would need no more than USD50/bbl for the US to grow at 1mb/d on average over 2017-20E. Against this backdrop, we lower our long-term oil price forecasts from USD60/bbl to USD50/bbl.
